articles.headline: Want a Yogurt With That Venti Latte? Starbucks and Danone to Join Forces
articles.snippet: Entering one of the hottest categories in food today, Starbucks will sell a yogurt jointly branded with Danone of France.
articles.abstract: Entering one of the hottest categories in food today, Starbucks will sell a yogurt jointly branded with Danone of France.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starbucks is taking on the thriving market for yogurt, teaming up with French dairy powerhouse Danone to create a line of yogurts that will be sold in the coffee company’s stores and in grocery stores.

articles.headline: Legacy on Line in Fierce Drive on Health Law
articles.snippet: With the health care rollout on Oct. 1, an Obama administration team of political operators and data-crunching technocrats is working to sell the law to Americans.
articles.abstract: With the health care rollout on Oct. 1, an Obama administration team of political operators and data-crunching technocrats is working to sell the law to Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Denis R. McDonough, the White House chief of staff, first saw the document in a meeting in the Roosevelt Room, he immediately dispatched his aides to the West Wing basement to get copies for all of President Obama’s top advisers.

articles.headline: Apple Tops Expectations on Strong iPhone Sales
articles.snippet: The company said it had $6.9 billion in profit in the latest quarter, when it sold 31.2 million iPhones and 14.6 million iPads.
articles.abstract: The company said it had $6.9 billion in profit in the latest quarter, when it sold 31.2 million iPhones and 14.6 million iPads.
articles.lead_paragraph: The news on Tuesday was not particularly good for Apple: revenue was flat, profit was lower, and even the sales of iPads were down.

articles.headline: Pro-Baby, but Stingy With Money to Support Them
articles.snippet: Conservatives claim to have a soft spot for babies, but they also support sharp cuts to programs that benefit families and children.
articles.abstract: Conservatives claim to have a soft spot for babies, but they also support sharp cuts to programs that benefit families and children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Conservatives have a particularly soft spot for babies. They tend to have more children than liberals and they are much more likely to oppose abortion rights. They also appreciate babies’ power.

articles.headline: Food Corporations Turn to Chefs in a Quest for Healthy Flavor
articles.snippet: At companies like PepsiCo and Kellogg, white-coated lab technicians join with white-jacketed chefs to give consumers the taste they want with less salt, fat and sugar.
articles.abstract: At companies like PepsiCo and Kellogg, white-coated lab technicians join with white-jacketed chefs to give consumers the taste they want with less salt, fat and sugar.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. HELENA, Calif. — The chicken thighs, smoked for two hours, then soaked in buttermilk spiked with Crystal hot sauce and dredged in flour, turned a perfect golden brown, full of the promise of succulence and crunch, under the stern watch of Chef H. Alexander Talbot.

articles.headline: Criminal Indictment Is Expected for SAC Capital Advisors
articles.snippet: The government is said to be poised to announce the indictment of SAC Capital, the hedge fund led by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, which could lead to the fund’s demise.
articles.abstract: The government is said to be poised to announce the indictment of SAC Capital, the hedge fund led by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, which could lead to the fund’s demise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities are poised to level a criminal indictment against SAC Capital Advisors, the hedge fund run by the billionaire Steven A. Cohen, capping a nearly decade-long insider trading investigation into one of Wall Street’s most prominent firms.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Students Recall Special Schools Run Like Jails
articles.snippet: Boarding schools that are part of a “tough love” network based in Utah are coming under fire for accusations that the troubled youth in their care were routinely abused.
articles.abstract: Boarding schools that are part of a “tough love” network based in Utah are coming under fire for accusations that the troubled youth in their care were routinely abused.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Alexander Chomakhidze and his family moved to the United States from Greece a few years ago, he became so despondent he started skipping school and even tried to kill himself. Worried, his parents sent him to Horizon Academy, a Utah boarding school that promised therapy.

articles.headline: House G.O.P. Sets New Offensive on Obama Goals
articles.snippet: As President Obama prepares to lay out his economic plans, Republicans are proposing the biggest cuts since 1995, delivering blow after blow to programs he will promote as vital.
articles.abstract: As President Obama prepares to lay out his economic plans, Republicans are proposing the biggest cuts since 1995, delivering blow after blow to programs he will promote as vital.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Congressional Republicans are moving to gut many of President Obama’s top priorities with the sharpest spending cuts in a generation and a new push to hold government financing hostage unless the president’s signature health care law is stripped of money this fall.

articles.headline: Legal Battle Lifts Profile of a Quiet Empire
articles.snippet: A legal battle over an obscure investment trust lays bare the private world of Barry Portnoy, who oversees a $25 billion real estate empire stretching from Boston to Honolulu.
articles.abstract: A legal battle over an obscure investment trust lays bare the private world of Barry Portnoy, who oversees a $25 billion real estate empire stretching from Boston to Honolulu.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is a quiet American fortune, a $25 billion empire stretching from Boston to Honolulu that is rarely noticed outside tight business circles.
